metadata.case_name: Appellant (IPS Officer) v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Appellant appointed to the Indian Police Service on October 1, 1949, and posted to the State of Punjab.
Appellant held charge as Superintendent of Police in various districts but was reverted as Assistant Superintendent of Police in August 1957.
Appellant eventually posted to Dharamsala in March 1958.

In March 1958, appellant informed that it was proposed to take action against him under r. 5 of the All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955, framed under s. 3 of the All-India Services Act, 1951.
Appellant placed under suspension under r. 7 of the Rules pending disciplinary proceedings.
Shri K. L. Bhudiraja appointed as enquiry officer to hold the departmental enquiry against appellant.
Notice issued to appellant by the Enquiry Officer in July 1958.

Appellant made an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the Punjab High Court challenging the constitutionality of the All-India Services Act, 1951 and the legality of the enquiry against him.
Punjab High Court dismissed the application on July 30, 1958, in Civil Writ Application No. 732 of 1958.
Punjab High Court dismissed appellant's application for a certificate to appeal to Supreme Court next day.
Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.
President passed Constitution (Removal of Difficulties) Order No. II on January 26, 1950, adapting Art. 312 by omitting the clause requiring Council of States resolution.
Order No. II to continue until both Houses of Parliament constituted and summoned for first session.
All-India Services Act, 1951 enacted by provisional Parliament.
All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955 promulgated.

legal_issues.text: Whether the amendment made by the President in Art. 312 by Constitution (Removal of Difficulties) Order No. II of January 26, 1950, was in excess of power under Art. 392.
Whether provisional Parliament was competent to enact the All-India Services Act, 1951, without compliance with condition precedent under Art. 312.
Whether Rules promulgated in 1955 were bad as repugnant to Art. 312 after the Order ceased to have effect.

Whether Art. 312 laid a mandate on Parliament to make law regulating recruitment and conditions of service of all-India services and Parliament could not delegate this to Central Government, making s. 3 of the Act invalid.
Whether delegation made by s. 3 of the Act was excessive.
Whether Punjab Government had authority to institute proceedings under the Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: President's adaptation in Art. 312 by omitting clause requiring Council of States resolution exceeded power under Art. 392; proper adaptation would substitute 'provisional Parliament' for 'Council of States'.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 392, Art. 312; Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisional Parliament not competent to enact Act in 1951 without resolution as per Art. 312.
Rules of 1955 repugnant to Art. 312 as original words reappeared after Order expired, no Council of States resolution.
Art. 312 mandates Parliament to regulate recruitment and conditions of service itself, no delegation possible; s. 3 invalid.
Even if delegation possible, s. 3 excessive as no policy or standard laid down.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Laws Act case; words in Art. 312, 245, 138 etc.

petitioner_arguments.text: Punjab Government has no authority to institute enquiry as charges serious, likely leading to dismissal/removal by Central Government.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 392 gives wide power to President for adaptations by modification, addition or omission to remove difficulties during transition; omission of clause in Art. 312 valid as expedient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: President could choose omission; Sankari Prasad does not limit to specific manner.

court_reasoning.text: Once adaptation valid, no condition precedent for provisional Parliament to pass Act; Rules valid under Act, unaffected by reappearance of words in Art. 312.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules derive force from valid Act.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 312 does not prohibit delegation; regulation requires numerous rules changeable per exigencies, not all by Parliament.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'Parliament may by law provide' do not exclude delegation.

court_reasoning.text: No excessive delegation: s.4 adopts existing rules as policy/standard; s.3 requires consultation with States, laying before Parliament subject to modification.
Punjab Government, as 'Government' under which appellant serving (r.2(b)), authorized to institute enquiry under r.5; Central Government involved only if major penalty proposed post-enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Enquiry by serving State Government even for Central penalties.

holdings.text: President's adaptation of Art. 312 under Art. 392 valid.
Provisional Parliament competent to enact All-India Services Act, 1951.
Delegation under s.3 of Act permitted by Art. 312.
Punjab Government authorized to institute enquiry.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Adaptation under Art. 392 in Art. 368 left special majority untouched, emphasizing wide power.
Legislature can delegate rule-making; essential function is policy determination.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajnarain Singh v. The Chairman, Patna Administration Committee, Patna
precedents_cited.relevance: Delegation can authorize executive to modify law but not essential features.

statutes_cited.name: All-India Services Act, 1951 (LXI of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers Central Government to make rules after consulting States; adopts existing rules; rules laid before Parliament.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 312 enables law for all-India services; Art. 392 for adaptations; others compared for delegation.

statutes_cited.name: All-India Services (Discipline and Appeal) Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for penalties, enquiries; authority of State/Central Government.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Removal of Difficulties) Order No. II
statutes_cited.relevance: Adapted Art. 312 by omitting Council of States clause.

outcome.summary: All six contentions raised by appellant rejected; Act and Rules held constitutional and valid; Punjab Government authorized to proceed with enquiry.

key_quotes.text: The power given to the President under Art. 392 was very wide and it cannot be said that he could make the adaptation in one way and not in another.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds validity of President's omission in Art. 312.

key_quotes.text: Regulation of recruitment and conditions of service requires numerous and varied rules, which may have to be changed from time to time as the exigencies of public service require.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: s. 4 did lay down that the existing rules will govern the two all-India services... and in so far as it did so it determined the legislative policy and set up a standard.
key_quotes.speaker: court
